abstract: Companies that have rejected hierarchies have typically lacked diversity and, in at least one case, faced scandal. A new crop of them is aiming to find a middle ground.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Claypoole was taking her dog to day care when she bumped into Eric Ward, one of the chief executives at Ag Biome, a North Carolina biotechnology company where she is head of human resources. When the day-care receptionist asked how they knew each other, she said, “Well, he’s kind of my boss.” Mr. Ward cringed. Ag Biome operates with a “flat” business model: It eschews managers, favoring committees instead. Despite their titles, the co-founders, Scott Uknes and Mr. Ward, are, Ms. Claypoole said, “anti-C.E.O.s.”
headline: In Business, ‘Flat’ Structures Rarely Work. Is There a Solution?
keywords: Executives and Management (Theory);Labor and Jobs;Workplace Environment

abstract: Nokian Tyres of Finland made 80 percent of its tires in Russia, where energy was cheap. After losing billions, it prioritized political security over business efficiency.
lead_paragraph: Even with sheets of rain falling, the sprawling construction site was buzzing. Yellow and orange excavators slowly danced around a maze of muddy pits, swinging giant fistfuls of dirt as a chorus line of trucks traipsed across the landscape.
headline: The Ukraine War Changed This Company Forever
keywords: Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Factories and Manufacturing;Supply Chain;Embargoes and Sanctions;International Relations;Relocation of Business;Corporations;Tires;Labor and Jobs;Europe;Finland;Helsinki (Finland);Romania;Nokian Tyres Plc;Oradea (Romania)

abstract: As the country ventures beyond the West, it is revisiting its sense of self.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It’s not often that the publication of a policy paper is cause for excitement. But when the German government set out the country’s first national security strategy in June, it set off a flurry of coverage. The document, in the end, was a bit of a disappointment. Partly that was because, for all its focus on pressing matters of foreign policy, it seemed to miss something significant: a clear change in the country’s orientation. For the first time in the postwar period, Germany is paying proper attention to the rest of the world.
headline: Germany Is Learning a Hard Lesson
keywords: Germany;International Relations;Politics and Government;Scholz, Olaf (1958- );Holocaust and the Nazi Era;Reparations;Namibia

abstract: An outburst of tit-for-tat violence in Israel and the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Hours after Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, said last night that a military incursion aimed at Palestinian armed groups in the West Bank city of Jenin was wrapping up, five rockets were fired from the Gaza Strip into Israel, raising fears of more violence. No injuries were reported, and the Israeli military said the country’s air defense system had intercepted all five rockets.
headline: Your Wednesday Briefing

abstract: The nation needs to chart a new course on federal debt.
lead_paragraph: The federal debt is as old as the nation, and adding to it is sometimes prudent. For governments confronting existential crises like wars or pandemics, borrowing makes sense as a way to mobilize national resources, as the economist Barry Eichengreen wrote in the 2021 book “In Defense of Public Debt.” Government borrowing and spending are necessary to stimulate the economy during recessions. And Treasuries, safe and liquid, play a critical role in the global financial system — so much so that in the late 1990s, when a period of economic growth and reduced military spending allowed the government to sharply reduce borrowing, economists and bankers raised alarms about the consequences of too little federal debt.
headline: America Is Living on Borrowed Money
keywords: National Debt (US);Federal Budget (US);United States Politics and Government;United States Economy;Democratic Party;Republican Party

abstract: An inmate hoped to start over with a clean slate by fighting in Ukraine. Instead, he was confronted by the drudgery of trench work and the terror of battle. “You’re going in as meat,” he said he was told.
lead_paragraph: The Russian soldier was captured only days after arriving on the front line in eastern Ukraine. He had little training. But he knew how to disassemble and fire his rifle and where to put a tourniquet.
headline: ‘Dig, Dig, Dig’: A Russian Soldier’s Story
keywords: Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Defense and Military Forces;Prisoners of War;Draft and Recruitment (Military);Ex-Convicts;Ukraine;Russia

abstract: A new movie documents George Michael and Andrew Ridgeley’s storming of the pop airwaves as the duo Wham! and laughs past the thorny questions.
lead_paragraph: The new documentary about George Michael, Andrew Ridgeley and the music they made as Wham! — it’s just called “Wham!” — found me in a moment of need for a nostalgic, fantastical elixir, something short, sweet and tangential to my feeling of national blues. For one thing, Wham!, the duo, made soul music that popped. And the movie dances past all of the thorny moral and ethical questions of white people making Black stuff. Those questions don’t exist at all in this movie. That’s the fantasy. And I’m here for it. But also: Wham! didn’t have any thorns.
headline: ‘Wham!’ Review: They Made It Big, Then Broke Up
keywords: Movies;Documentary Films and Programs;Michael, George;Smith, Chris (1970- );Wham! (Music Group);Pop and Rock Music;Wham! (Movie);Ridgeley, Andrew

headline: How to Deal With Financial Trauma

lead_paragraph: It was 6 a.m. — 2 a.m. to my raddled East Coast brain — and my husband, daughter and I were staggering through customs in the Ponta Delgada Airport, on the island of São Miguel, the largest of the nine islands that make up Portugal’s Azores archipelago.
headline: In the Azores: Earth, Water, Fire and Air, Sometimes All at Once
keywords: Travel and Vacations;Azores Islands;Sao Miguel (Azores)

abstract: Flavor and texture take top billing in a simple Jamaican dish.
lead_paragraph: When I cook for myself, the only real guideline I follow is the pursuit of flavor — everything else is a suggestion. And sometimes, particularly with a cuisine I’m not too familiar with, this means following a recipe to the letter. But more often than not, pleasure is the goal, which means steamed cabbage and carrots sprinkled with shichimi togarashi; or Red Stripe-marinated chicken, battered in potato starch, fried and slathered with miso mayo; or, among friends, a whole fried snapper served alongside basil, fried shallots, sa tế and lettuce, for wrapping. Usually, it’s in this quest for flavor that I realize what’s actually most comforting for me in a given moment.
headline: This Melon Salad Is Pure Pleasure
keywords: Jamaica (West Indies);Cooking and Cookbooks;Recipes;Moore, Denai (1993- )

abstract: As regulated monopolies, utilities have the unique ability to force customers to fund their political activities through monthly bills.
lead_paragraph: To avoid the worst impacts of climate change, we have to make two big transitions at once: First, we have to generate all of our electricity from clean sources, like wind turbines and solar panels, rather than power plants that run on coal and methane gas. Second, we have to retool nearly everything else that burns oil and gas — like cars, buses and furnaces that heat buildings — to run on that clean electricity.
headline: Guess Who’s Been Paying to Block Green Energy. You Have.
keywords: Electric Light and Power;Global Warming;Alternative and Renewable Energy;Solar Energy;Wind Power;Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline;Natural Gas;State Legislatures;Law and Legislation;Lobbying and Lobbyists;Campaign Finance;United States Politics and Government;United States

abstract: Christina Quarles discusses representation, trades and protein shakes.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Los Angeles as the fair-skinned daughter of a Black father and a white mother, Christina Quarles, 38, can recall the first time her sense of identity was challenged: “In elementary school, there was this book of famous Black people throughout history and my nana was in there,” she said. (Her paternal grandmother, Norma Quarles, was one of the first Black TV journalists.) “I would show the other kids that was my grandmother in the book but get told, ‘No, you’re not Black.’ It was this disconnect between how I was raised with my own personal sense of my biography, and then to be met with such resistance when I would express that to people.”
headline: An Artist Whose Language Is Painting
keywords: Quarles, Christina (1985- );Content Type: Personal Profile;Art

abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is getting a lot of play, but his views are in the minority.
lead_paragraph: With Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, vaccine skepticism has been back in the headlines. Though Kennedy has said he isn’t anti-vaccine and that his children have had vaccines, and his campaign manager (the former Democratic congressman and presidential candidate Dennis Kucinich) says calling Kennedy “anti-vax” is a “left-handed smear,” Kennedy continues to suggest a link between vaccines and autism — a link that has leaned heavily on flawed and retracted science. He’s also been a vocal opponent of Covid vaccines.
headline: Pro-Vaccine Views Are Winning. Don’t Fear the Skeptics.
keywords: internal-sub-only-nl;Kennedy, Robert F Jr;Vaccination and Immunization;Primaries and Caucuses;Polls and Public Opinion;Presidential Election of 2024;Democratic Party;Republican Party

abstract: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.
headline: Easy Mode: Clues for Friday, July 7, 2023
keywords: internal-sub-only-games

abstract: After ending a yearslong extramarital affair, a reader worries about a coming dinner party that will be attended by both the former lover and the reader’s spouse.
lead_paragraph: I had an extramarital affair for several years. It ended recently — abruptly and unpleasantly — and I blocked all digital and telephonic communication with my ex to ensure that I don’t weaken and get involved again. The affair was fulfilling sexually and emotionally, but it was also taboo: We are both otherwise happily married and socialize together as couples. Now, I am apprehensive about future encounters. Recently, we all juggled our calendars to attend a small, upcoming dinner party at a third couple’s home. How should I handle this? I don’t want to reach out and ask for a truce; my emotions are still too raw — with hurt and anger not far from the surface. I don’t know how to justify canceling the dinner to my spouse, but I’m afraid I may lose it if I go.
headline: I Had an Affair With Someone My Spouse and I See Socially. Help!
keywords: Customs, Etiquette and Manners;Content Type: Service

abstract: Sgah’gahsowáh, the artist behind the one-man band, combines the genre’s traditional heavy sounds with a focus on nature. His new album, “Blackbraid II,” is out Friday.
lead_paragraph: Black metal has long been associated with the gray skies, snowy landscapes and Norse mythology of Scandinavia. Most people know it, if at all, as the musical genre associated with church burnings and gory homicides in early 1990s Norway. (Those events were documented in the book “Lords of Chaos,” which was adapted into a 2019 feature starring Rory Culkin as the misanthropic, occultist musician Euronymous.)
headline: Meet Blackbraid, a Black Metal Musician With Native American Roots

abstract: After his wrongful conviction as one of the Central Park Five was overturned, Mr. Salaam found it hard to rebuild his life. Now he stands to take office next year.
lead_paragraph: This week, 34 years after he and four other teenage boys who barely knew one another were bound together by notorious failures of justice, Yusef Salaam was officially declared the winner in the Democratic primary for a seat in New York’s City Council, having received almost 64 percent of the vote. Given that more than three-quarters of voters in the district identify as Democrats, we can assume that beginning in January, he will represent Harlem, where he grew up, was arrested and returned after serving nearly seven years in prison for a crime he did not commit.
headline: For Yusef Salaam, a Landslide Just Might Be the Best Revenge
keywords: Elections, City Councils;Primaries and Caucuses;Content Type: Personal Profile;Central Park Jogger Case (1989);City Council (NYC);Salaam, Yusef;Jordan, Kristin Richardson (1987- );Harlem (Manhattan, NY);Democratic Party;New York City

abstract: The Florida governor, who has yet to demonstrate himself as a campaigner on a national stage, has been plagued by a series of unforced errors and has yet to make a strong case against Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, looking to shift his run for president into a higher gear after an early series of missteps, spent the last two weeks rolling out an immigration policy and holding town halls with voters. But rather than correcting course, he stumbled again this week, raising questions about where his campaign is heading.
headline: DeSantis Campaign Continues to Struggle to Find Its Footing
keywords: DeSantis, Ron;Republican Party;Primaries and Caucuses;Presidential Election of 2024;United States Politics and Government;Polls and Public Opinion;Trump, Donald J

abstract: Nancy Yao was to lead a Smithsonian museum about the influence of American women. Her withdrawal came amid a review of how she had handled sexual harassment complaints in an earlier post.
lead_paragraph: The Smithsonian’s choice for the founding director of its developing American Women’s History Museum has withdrawn from the role, the institution said Wednesday.
headline: Director of New Women’s History Museum Withdraws, Citing Family Issues
keywords: Yao, Nancy;Smithsonian American Women's History Museum;Museums;Appointments and Executive Changes;Sexual Harassment;Workplace Hazards and Violations;Museum of Chinese in America;Washington (DC)

abstract: Want to see new art in New York this weekend? Check out Behjat Sadr’s earthy canvases in Greenwich Village or rafa esparza’s portraits in TriBeCA. And don’t miss John Fahey’s works on paper in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Want to see new art in New York this weekend? Check out “Luxe, Calme, Volupté” on the Lower East Side or “Reclamation” at Hudson Yards. And don’t miss Rachel Rossin’s “mechs” in Chinatown.
headline: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in July

abstract: They said a restriction on government interaction with social media companies could impede efforts to curb false claims about vaccines and voter fraud.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge’s decision this week to restrict the government’s communication with social media platforms could have broad side effects, according to researchers and groups that combat hate speech, online abuse and disinformation: It could further hamper efforts to curb harmful content.
headline: Disinformation Researchers Fret About Fallout From Judge’s Order
keywords: Social Media;Computers and the Internet;Rumors and Misinformation;Freedom of Speech and Expression;Hate Speech;Research;Courts and the Judiciary;Doughty, Terry A;Decisions and Verdicts

abstract: Former Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City and his wife, Chirlane McCray, announced they were separating after growing apart. Here’s what experts advise if you’re wondering about your own relationship.
lead_paragraph: Former Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City and his wife, Chirlane McCray, announced that they were separating after nearly 30 years in an interview with The New York Times on Wednesday. Their story begins with an “aha” moment in the midst of what the article calls yet another “stale Saturday night of binge-watching television” together.
headline: How to Talk About Marital Unhappiness Before It’s Too Late
keywords: Marriages;Therapy and Rehabilitation;Content Type: Service;de Blasio, Bill;McCray, Chirlane;Divorce, Separations and Annulments

abstract: Here’s what to know about Instagram’s new app for public conversations and how it differs from Twitter.
lead_paragraph: After months of speculation and secrecy, Mark Zuckerberg’s long-rumored competitor app to Twitter is here.
headline: Threads, Instagram’s ‘Twitter Killer,’ Has Arrived
keywords: Threads (Mobile App);Meta Platforms Inc;Zuckerberg, Mark E;Social Media;Mosseri, Adam;Mobile Applications;Instagram Inc;Musk, Elon;Twitter

abstract: Ukrainian and Russian officials differed on whether a military or civilian area had been struck. Earlier in the war, Russia lost dozens of soldiers, if not hundreds, in a strike on the city.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s military launched an overnight strike on the Russian-occupied city of Makiivka, showing that it could still attack targets deep behind Russian lines as its troops fight in grueling trench warfare in a counteroffensive to reclaim land.
headline: Ukraine Strikes a Russian-Occupied City, Igniting a Huge Blast
keywords: Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Defense and Military Forces;Makiivka (Ukraine);Ukraine;Russia;Deaths (Fatalities);Bombs and Explosives

abstract: By striking down affirmative action, justices take the absurd position that racism must be ignored for racism to be overcome.
lead_paragraph: There is a recurrent theme in American history: the clawing back of hard-won progress. And the Supreme Court last week used the most specious of arguments to do so with affirmative action.
headline: The Supreme Court Didn’t Put Racism on a Leash. It Granted It License.
keywords: Colleges and Universities;Discrimination;Black People;Blacks;Race and Ethnicity;Admissions Standards;Affirmative Action;Jackson, Ketanji Brown (1970- );Roberts, John G Jr;Thomas, Clarence;Decisions and Verdicts;Supreme Court (US)

abstract: A pop star across Asia by her early 20s, Ms. Lee reached international recognition with an Oscar-nominated song in 2001.
lead_paragraph: Coco Lee, a Chinese American singer and songwriter best known for performing an Oscar-nominated song in the hit film “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,” died on Wednesday in a hospital in Hong Kong. She was 48.
headline: Coco Lee, ‘Crouching Tiger’ and ‘Mulan’ Singer, Dies at 48
keywords: Lee, Coco (1975-2023);Deaths (Obituaries);Chinese-Americans;Pop and Rock Music;Movies;Mulan (Movie);Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (Movie)

abstract: The attacker faces sentencing after pleading guilty to federal hate crimes charges. “Why is it us in pain and not you?” asked one survivor of the rampage that killed 23.
lead_paragraph: Emotional testimony from survivors and victims’ families began on Wednesday in the federal sentencing hearing for the gunman who killed 23 people and injured dozens more at a Walmart store in El Paso, one of the deadliest attacks targeting Latinos in modern U.S. history.
headline: El Paso Gunman Is Confronted by Victims’ Families at Sentencing
keywords: Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Mass Shootings;Hate Crimes;Hispanic-Americans;El Paso, Tex, Shooting (2019);Crusius, Patrick (1998- );El Paso (Tex);Texas

abstract: People who lived with the suspect told investigators that he was wearing a bulletproof vest around the house in the days before five people were gunned down.
lead_paragraph: As the streets outside his home echoed with pops, Darryl Steplight thought it was fireworks on the eve of the Fourth of July. He quickly learned otherwise. A man in body armor, and carrying an AR-15-style rifle, had opened fire at random in the neighborhood, killing five and wounding two, including a 2-year-old.
headline: Suspect Showed Troubling Signs Before Philadelphia Rampage, D.A. Says
keywords: Mass Shootings;Philadelphia (Pa);Carriker, Kimbrady
